title: The 5 Stages of Fibromyalgia Grief

content: Denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. Those are the five stages of grief coined by Elisabeth Kübler-Ross, MD.
You may have gone through those stages when you lost a close relative or beloved pet. Maybe you’ve grieved losing a house, or a favorite job, or a canceled vacation.

A fibromyalgia diagnosis is another reason to mourn. You may be grieving the experiences you’re missing out on or the time you’re losing. Maybe you’re in mourning about a hobby you can no longer do or a job you can no longer work.
Maybe you’re going through Kübler-Ross’s five stages. But I wonder if I have five stages that ring truer.
I think that the five stages of grief we go through after a fibromyalgia diagnosis are decompression, dread, desperation, distress, and determination.
Decompression
When my doctor diagnosed me with fibromyalgia, I smiled. I felt stress exit my body like air from a balloon. An answer! Such relief! That diagnosis felt like a magical gift.

I think that the five stages of grief we go through after a fibromyalgia diagnosis are decompression, dread, desperation, distress, and determination.
Decompression
When my doctor diagnosed me with fibromyalgia, I smiled. I felt stress exit my body like air from a balloon. An answer! Such relief! That diagnosis felt like a magical gift.

content: Like the correct key to a stubborn lock.
The diagnosis told me what I had but also what I didn’t. I didn’t have cancer. I didn’t have multiple sclerosis. I wasn’t going to die.
So I unwound. I relaxed. I sighed with relief. I decompressed.
Dread
For me, fear followed the relief rather quickly. New stress replaced the old. I thought:
I’m scared that this will ruin my life.
I’m afraid that I’ll never feel well again.
Will the pain get worse?
Will I still be able to work when I’m fatigued?
How can I live my life when I’m exhausted and in pain all the time?
Desperation
When I use the word desperation, I don’t mean that sensation of nervousness. I mean that urgent oh-my-god-I-need-answers now energy right in my stomach.

I started researching fibromyalgia, desperate to learn more. I started reaching out to other people, hoping they had wisdom to share. I started connecting with doctors, desperate for them to tell me they found a cure.

content: I often regress back to the desperation stage. Desperate for good news, I dive back into research. Hours pass.
Distress
Fibromyalgia is distressing. It makes me sad, sorrowful. I feel distressed especially when I research for hours and find zero new information.
I also feel distress when I want to do an activity, but can’t because I’m in too much pain. I’m forever missing out, and often wonder if this is really living!
Determination
The final stage of grief is determination. It’s that resiliency that rises up from the deepest part of me. Determination says:
I will thrive despite the cards I’ve been dealt.
I will manage my condition to the best of my ability so that I have more good days.
I will move forward, live forward.
I release my old life and embrace the new.
I will find new ways to live a fulfilling life.
I will not let fibromyalgia define me.
The 5 Ds

content: Grief follows no schedule. Sometimes it lies dormant and I think it’s gone away, but then it grabs me by the throat again.
Grief follows no order. I can go from the desperation stage to decompression to determination.
Grief follows no timeline. Sometimes I go through several stages in a day. Sometimes I’ll live in one stage for a year.
I’ll end with this advice: Grieve fibromyalgia. Let yourself mourn. Go through the stages as many times as you need, for as long as you need.
And if you can, live in the fifth stage. Live with determination.
